posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
This is another one of my “guilty pleasure” builds, and he’s street legal.  He bears similarities to Demos’ most excellent build, The Dreadnought , but with some slight tweakings and modifications.  He is a beast of war, and he makes no apologies for it.  He brings to the battlefield a devastating halberd capable of 2 damage types with a possible Devastating Dirtnap DC of 50.  He achieves and maintains 9/- Damage Reduction, high hit points, good saves, excellent skill set, and rich complement of battle techniques, to include Improved Knockdown, Improved Disarm, and a competitive taunt score.  He matures early and often, and is a welcome respite to those namby pamby Lasting Inspiration Bards (admittedly, those are fun too and arguably more powerful).  I can’t help but think that any dwarf who has their blood ignited by some latent dragon heritage would become an outcast, a pariah, of their clan.  After all, the only good dragon is a dead dragon.  Akin to those drow who walk the surface world, they have no home, no family, no going back – only the hellfire burning in their blood, and the insatiable lust to conquer all.  Probably outlawed on most persistent worlds….

Decent Saves, especially against spells
 
Weaknesses
Not much of a self-buffer, must rely on UMD, potions etc.  Not a weakness per se, but many folks like that option.
 
Related Builds – there are several similar in design or concept, but they aren’t as playable in my opinion.  The closest would be Xylophones’ Munchkin the Dwarf Dragon Wannabe: Link here or Cinnabar Din’s Master of Resistance (which opts for a slew of resistances and saves) Link here
 
Other related Builds: 
The Draconic Professor of War: Link here
 
The Dreadnought:  Link here  The primary differences between the Dreadnought and the Dragonwrought Dwarflord are small:  the Dwarflord receives 48 more hit points, has Improved Disarm, obtains Dev Crit 1 level earlier, and uses a two-handed weapon with 2 damage types.  He loses 4 skill points to the Dreadnought, and 1 rank on Will and Reflex Saves to the Dreadnought, but makes up for it with +1 on Fort saves. 
 
 
Builder’s Commentary:
As alluded to earlier, this is a melee fighter.  He doesn’t rely on Buffs or Songs.  Blindfighting is taken at Level 9 because that’s typically where one needs it when you start coming across critters with various forms of concealment.  Not much to say other than that.  While you do have a good skill set, at 199 skill points you have to prioritize.  Bard Levels or solely for Taunt, Tumble, UMD (and Perform for a bit) skill investments.  With 4 Bard levels taken, these are spaced evenly throughout the build, 2 pre-epic to maximize UMD and Tumble, and the same in Epic. 
 
Discipline skill points can be redistributed if you’re not worried about KD or Disarms.  I tend to do this and cross class points into Search and Open Lock.
 
With some good Constitution gear and a Potion of Endurance, you can get hit points well over 800.
 
The only other race that can achieve this same set of battle goodness is Half-orc.  One would just start with Str18 and Con16.  However, Half-orc is still inferior because of 20% xp penalty, lower skill points, and slightly lower saves against Spells.
 
Other notes: My skillpoint math might be off by one since the 1.79 patch is applying the bonus after the level.  If so, you may subtract 1 from either Taunt or Discipline.

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content: That looks about right.  Skill points are often the most fluid of things to adjust as one levels.  For instance, one may decide that they don't need those points in Discipline, or Taunt, and choose to crossclass Search, some Open Lock, Appraise, etc.  I try not to be too pedantic about allocation because environments will often dictate what is important.  And I think you're right about my Discipline/Taunt mix up.  That should be reversed.  Good catch!

Is it worth losing the damage from a 2 handed weapon for the extra AC from Hammer and board, maybe packing an axe for alternative damage type?

Sent from my I3312 using Tapatalk

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
The only real difference will be no .5 of str bonus to damage, as warhammer and halberd are pretty near to each other in base damage (1d8 vs 1d10).

About 10 damage less (factoring in +12 to Str), depending on what bonuses to str are present in your environment.

So you are basically trading damage for ac.

The exception, of course, is that the halberd threatens two different types of physical damage and, depending on your environment, that could make a difference.

posts.content: I think in Mines of Twin Summits I'll be fine with the hammer and the AC will be more useful. I'll keep a greataxe on standby for the few blunt resistant monsters that are there.

posts.author: Ant_
posts.content:
Its the most recent topic on a Fighter/Bard/RDD, so im going to throw my question out here.

Alot of the low Bard variants lack anti stealth skills, how do these Charachters fare in WoG or other challanging environments? And without a single point in search/spot all those hidden doors etc. Remain hidden forever.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
You don't really need anti-stealth skills much on WoG - the enemy will find you just fine!

You don't need spot, but Search is necessary, so a few points here is a must.  The rest comes from UMD and items.
